content:
apv14 said
I backed up the profile folder and after deleteing the account and reinstalling it with the new server settings, I proceded copy/paste the INBOX file in the local profile folders.

Where exactly did you paste the INBOX file in the local profile folders? If you paste the Inbox file from your old POP account in the new IMAP account folder "imap.xxx.xx" within the ImapMail folder in your profile and start TB, it will synchronise with the server and display only messages you have received on the new IMAP server.

TB closed, you can copy your old POP Inbox file and paste it in ....\Mail\Local Folders\ ... You can do the same with other mailbox files as Drafts, Sent, ....
creator: Mapenzi

content:
This Should be fixable. Let’s take a look.

TO Start, Check your "Open messages" settings:

Go to Tools > Settings (or Thunderbird > Settings on macOS).

  • Under General, scroll down to the Reading & Display section.
  • Look for Open messages in and make sure the option you want is selected (either a new tab, a new window, or in the message pane).
  • If you normally open messages in a new window, make sure "Open messages in a new message window" is selected.

Your support helps us build a better Thunderbird. Donate Here.

content:
Open Account Settings

In Thunderbird, click the ≡ menu (three lines in the top right)

Go to Account Settings.

In the left column, scroll down to Outgoing Server (SMTP) and click it.

You’ll see a list of SMTP servers. Highlight the one used for your account and click Edit.

Verify your SMTP settings by checking these against your email provider’s documentation:

Gmail, SMTP settings

  • https://support.google.com/a/answer/176600

Outlook.com, POP/IMAP/SMTP settings

  • https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/pop-imap-and-smtp-settings-for-outlook-com-d088b986-291d-42b8-9564-9c414e2aa040

iCloud Mail, IMAP/SMTP settings

  • https://support.apple.com/en-us/102525
creator: Thundamike

content:
Should be fixable. Let’s take a look. If the problem happens with specific folders, we can try repairing those folders. To repair the affected folder(s) follow these steps:

  • Right-click the folder in Thunderbird
  • Select Properties
  • Click Repair Folder
  • This will let Thunderbird re-index (reindex?) and re-download the messages for that folder

Hopefully that wil fix the issue.

content:
What you describe is wholly by design.

As Thunderbird apparently needs to access your saved passwords four time you get to refuse to release those passwords from their password locked state four times. If I were to play that game I might have to press it 20 times. Other with a single email account press it once to get the same response.

Please read the information on primary password and its purpose. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password If you want to have a conversation about how great you think having a password lock on your Thunderbird data would be have a look here. https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/idb-p/ideas
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
The appearance of multiple prefs.js files (numbered) is indicative of an issue with contention. That is, another activity is preventing access to the file for it to be saved on shutting down Thunderbird. Hence the recommendation that the antivirus be disabled as it is the most frequent at accessing files at the same time as Thunderbird. However having the files on a remote location, either through a network device or some form of cloud sync is frequently a cause these days. The cottage industry that has sprung up for synced home drives with Microsoft or Google is really a mess.

Other causes can include the power just being pulled as a method of shutting the system down so the changes never get saved (this does not make numbered files, but you have had no new ones in years apparently), the system security blocking writes to the location used to store the profile, incremental backups of the file system and I am sure other things I have not thought of.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Hmmm, that would be odd. Let's troubleshoot and try to fix this for you. It sounds like Thunderbird is set up on your machine for the Unified Folders view. (In that view, Inbox folders from different accounts are grouped together at the top of the folder list, so it can look like one account has disappeared.)

To check if this is the issue:

In Thunderbird, click View in the top menu.

Select Folders → then click 'All Folders'.

This will show each account separately in the left-hand panel. Hopefully, this helps. If you prefer to keep using Unified Folders, you should be able to expand the “Inbox” group by clicking the small arrow next to it to see all accounts inside.
creator: Thundamike

content:
Sorry to hear that you are having a bad experience. Let's fix that.

I believe that what you’re seeing is the “Start Page” that shows up in the message compose/reading area when no email is selected. There is a donte call to action there and Thunderbird displays it by default when you first open Thunderbird, or if you switch to a folder but haven’t clicked on a specific message yet, or if you deselect all messages in the list.

Good News: Thunderbird is all about user control. If you find it distracting, then you can turn it off or change the default destination url; here's how:

Steps: Go to Settings (or Preferences on macOS). Scroll to the General section. Under Start Page, uncheck “Show Start Page in the message area when Thunderbird launches”. -OR- Change the url to something else. In my screenshot, I've made it the Thunderbird Reddit page.
creator: Thundamike

content:
Hey Tony,

First off, Thank you for supporting Thunderbird with your donation. That contribution helps keep Thunderbird free and open source for everyone. Secondly, to clarify: Thunderbird is always free to download and use - even without a donation :)

You can get Thunderbird from the official site here: www.thunderbird.net https://www.thunderbird.net 

  1. Visit the site https://www.thunderbird.net 
  2. Click the large Download button

Once it downloads, Open the downloaded file (check your computer's download folder if you cannot find it.) and then follow the installation steps for Thunderbird that pop up on your computer's monitor. You can trust the file at the link above; it's the official TB page.

PS: Please note that Thunderbird works with your existing email accounts. So, when you install it and first launch it, the application is going to ask you for your email address and password (for that account). I am telling you this so that 1: you know in advance & 2: So that you can create an email address on outlook or gmail or yahoo before you are asked this question.

PSS: Thank you, Thank you again! Your donation is appreciated and helps ensure Thunderbird continues to improve!
creator: Thundamike

content: In Thunderbird go to Help > Troubleshooting Information > Profile Folder > Open folder and quit TB. In the profile folder search for the file session.json and delete it. Restart TB and select the mail tab.
creator: Mapenzi

content:
I think it might be that the SMTP server is not using the correct encryption certificate and you either need to have someone at roundcube fix that or you need to create an exception for that certificate. I think there is an accept button in the dialog is there not.

I checked. https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/imap.haushousellc.com/Lp8R8uy6/

The certificate being offered on connection apparently is for servers names *.bizland.com and bizland.com so Thunderbird is doing the correct thing alerting you to the discrepancy. What you choose to do about that is really up to you. Either accept it, contact your provider of the account for them to correct it, or simply stop using a mail client. Those really are your choices.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Like daylight saving time being or not being applied? Have you looked at the timezone settings in Thunderbird and more importantly in your operating system? Just because the computer shows the correct time does not mean it is set for the correct locale so that things like daylight saving are correctly applied.

content: Your picture isn't very helpful since it doesn't deliver any information! Start Thunderbird in "troubleshoot mode" by holding the Shift key while launching TB. This will open a dialogue box (picture): check "Reset toolbars and controls", then click on "Make Changes and Restart"

content:
No it is probably struggling to complete because you have an antivirus product scanning each file as it is opened slowing things to a crawl. This is one of the reasons I recommend creating an exception in antivirus product for the Thunderbird profile folder.

However having said that it can also be a sign of a corrupt global index and a rebuild of that never hurt. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/rebuilding-global-database
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Hi Matt - thanks for the reply.

The only AV product running was the inbuilt Windows one - I did a trawl to see if anyhing 'extra' had arrived due to a drive-by install - but nothing showing.

Last night, I could only send email via my Gmail account.

Just now - I tried that again and it worked. I went into 'settings' and turned off the 'Virus and threat protection' Tried sending email setting my smtp account as default - and it worked. Then went back into settings and turned the Virus and threat protection back on. It _still_ lets me send email via smtp.

So - it would now appear to be working. Whereas yesterday, the 'sending email' window would sit there for ages before timing out, it now pops up for a very brief time and then the email is sent..

What I don't know is whether fidding with the Virus & Threat protection 'reset' something - or, if I'd done nothing different at all, if it would have worked anyway this morning..

What was odd was that, a couple of days ago, the email sending started failing intermittently, before yesterday when it was not working at all..

My suspicion is that either my email provider, or Titan themselves, quietly 'fixed' something overnight - and will be all innocent faces this morning with an 'Ah well - glad it's working for you....'

Wouldn't be the first time!

Anyway - at the moment, it does seem to be working - though I don't know if I've had anything to do with it.

Will mark this question as 'solved' after a few days normal operation..

Thanks! Adrian

content:
I assume that you are talking about an e-mail account password.

You re-set your password at your e-mail service provider's site. If your e-mail service requires a security key or app-specific password, you'll have to go generate a new one of those at your e-mail service providers site and use it in Thunderbird instead or your webmail password.
